IMAGE-THUMBNAIL APCATA 14622 S0926-860X(13)00767-9 10.1016/j.apcata.2013.12.023 Elsevier B.V. Line 1 refers to Na2Ti3O7 form. Photocatalytic activity of hyperbranched polyester/TiO2 nanocomposites A.F. Ghanem a A.A. Badawy b ⁎ N. Ismail b Z. Rayn Tian c M.H. Abdel Rehim d ⁎ A. Rabia e a Center of Excellence for Advanced Science, Renewable Energy Group, National Research Center, Egypt Center of Excellence for Advanced Science, Renewable Energy Group, National Research Center Egypt b Physical Chemistry Department, Center of Excellence for Advanced Science, Renewable Energy Group, National Research Center, Cairo, Egypt Physical Chemistry Department, Center of Excellence for Advanced Science, Renewable Energy Group, National Research Center Cairo Egypt c Chemistry/Biochemistry Department, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, USA Chemistry/Biochemistry Department, University of Arkansas Fayetteville AR 72701 USA d Packing and Packaging Materials Department, Center of Excellence for Advanced Science, Renewable Energy Group, National Research Center, Egypt Packing and Packaging Materials Department, Center of Excellence for Advanced Science, Renewable Energy Group, National Research Center Egypt e Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University Cairo Egypt ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +20 2 33322418; fax: +20 2 33370931. Graphical abstract TiO2 nanowires (NWs) were prepared by hydrothermal treatment of TiO2 nanoparticles in alkaline medium, while hyperbranched polyester HPES-OH was prepared by polycondensation. Chemical structure of HPES-OH was confirmed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy, FTIR and the molar mass was determined using gel permeation chromatography (GPC). Nanocomposites based on HPES-OH and TiO2 NWs are synthesized either by ex situ method or by in situ technique. Formation of the nanocomposites and investigation of their morphology were done using transmission electron microscope (TEM), scanning electron microscope (SEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). Photocatalytic activity of the synthesized nanocomposites compared to that of pure TiO2-NWs was studied. The chemical oxygen demand (COD) analysis confirmed the mineralization of wastewater via photocatalytic degradation. The results showed that not only photocatalytic activity of nanocomposites was much higher than that of the pure TiO2-NWs, but also the degradation time was reduced to large extent. This result can be attributed to reduction of the crystallite size produced due to the modification reaction. Durability of HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites was investigated and the results confirmed that utilization of the modified TiO2-NWs in the second run was favorable, which suggests that strong adhesion between the NWs and HPES-OH was achieved through the formation of 2D structure. Keywords Hyperbranched polymers Hydrothermal method Nanocomposites Photocatalyst 1 Introduction Titanium dioxide is non-toxic, photoetch-stable and inexpensive as one of the most effective semiconductor photocatalysts. Compared with as-catalysts, TiO2 nanorod/wire/tube arrays have relatively higher aspect ratio, lesser crystal interface, efficient charge separation and unique optical and electric properties. Many approaches have been reported to fabricate TiO2 nano arrays [1–4]. Therefore, TiO2 nano arrays have been widely applied in many fields, including solar energy batteries, photocatalyst and gas sensors [5–7]. TiO2 nano arrays, immobilized onto various supports, have improved properties in photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants [8,9], water photoelectrolysis [10,11] with the improvement of complicated separation performance of TiO2 power. Hyperbranched macromolecules (HBP) were firstly theoretically described in the 1950s [12], but synthesized in the early 1990s [13] and have been studied in detail since then [14,15]. HBP are readily synthesized through a one-pot [16] or pseudo-one-pot [17] synthesis. There are many reviews cover the different aspects and novel synthetic methodologies of HBP [18–21]. The main distinguishing merits of HBP are high molecular weight distribution and irregular branching, large number of end groups and low solution viscosity compared with their linear analog. Nevertheless, their simple method of synthesis presents a highly desired feature and facilitates commercial applications [16,22,23]. Nanocomposites based on hyperbranched polymers and inorganic nano-objects as main organic phase not as additive in combination with linear polymers were intensively studied [24–26]. Hyperbranched polyester/TiO2 nanohybrids were prepared via in situ sol gel method in the modified hyperbranched polyester matrix [27]. It was reported that modification was required to achieve good dispersion of the nanoparticles in the polymer matrix. The formed nanocomposite films showed better thermal properties and improved hardness compared to TiO2 free system. Phenolic compounds pose a significant threat to the environment. They are commonly found in industrial effluents and have been detected in urban and agricultural waste. Nitrophenolic compounds, for example, are released into the environment through their wide use as dyes, pesticides, plasticizers, and solvents. It was reported that some di-nitrophenol can be formed as degradation product of herbicide nitrofen when it was exposed to sunlight [28]. Recently, it was reported that simultaneous removal of toxic pollutants in water can be realized via O2-based photocatalytic reaction systems [29–31]. However, most applications in wastewater focus on TiO2 powder and nanoparticles [32,33]. Chemical oxygen demand (COD) is an important index of water quality. Organic pollutants present in wastewater are mainly characterized by this index. The COD content indicates the amount of organic containments and hence water clean degree. Coking wastewater is a kind of typical industrial wastewater. It contains various refractory pollutants which still exist after conventional physical, chemical and biological treatments, such as phenol. Owing to their high biotoxicity, the organic compounds in coking wastewater are not readily degradable [34] and result in high content of COD. Compared with biological oxidation and chemical treatments, heterogeneous photocatalysis over TiO2 have been proven to be effective for the removal of as-toxicants. The detailed mechanism of the photocatalytic process has been discussed extensively in literature [35–37]. In present work, nanocomposites based on hyperbranched polyester/TiO2 nanowires were prepared by in situ and ex situ methods. Photocatlytic properties of the formed nanocomposites were investigated in terms of value of COD removal and the results were compared with those obtained on using the pure TiO2 nanoparticles as photocatalyst. It will be shown that although HPES-OH has phenolic moieties, it did not suffer any degradation under photocatalytic reaction conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 4,4-bis(4-Hydroxy phenyl) valeric acid-95% monomer was obtained from Aldrich. 4-(Dimethylamino)pyridine (DMAP)-99%, P-toluene sulfonic acid monohydrate-98% and N,N-dicyclohexyl carbodiimide (DCC)-99%, were provided by Merck. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) with cross-sectional dimension about 30nm was obtained from Degussa. Sodium chloride (99%) and sodium hydroxide-(98%) were purchased from Honeywell, Germany and Macron Chemicals, Sweden, respectively. Dimethyl formamide (DMF) 99.9% was supplied from sigma Aldrich and dried over 3Å molecular sieves while benzene (99.7%) was imported from SD-Fine Chem, Ltd. and both used as received. The organic pollutants (phenol, sulfanilamide and N-(1-naphthyl)-ethylenediamine dichloride) were obtained from BDH Company and used without any further purification. All glassware was oven dried before use at 150°C. 2.2 Techniques The chemical structure of the prepared HBP could be assigned by 1H NMR and 13C NMR, the spectra of HBP were acquired on JEOL-ECA 500MHz spectrometer in DMSO at 250°C with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as internal standard. The spectra were measured at ∼300K using 5mm sample tubes. The functional groups in the HBP backbone were identified by FT-IR spectra which were recorded using Perkin Elmer Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. The determination of molecular weights and molecular weight distribution were carried out on a modular build SEC system coupled with a multi-angle laser light scattering (MALLS) detector DAWN EOS (Wyatt Technologies, USA) and a refractive index (RI) detector (Knauer, Germany) in combination with a PL-GEL 5mm mixed C column, 300mm×7.5mm (Polymer Laboratories, UK) using a flow rate of 1mL/min and DMAc as eluent. The structure and surface morphology of the prepared nanocomposites were examined using JEOL JEM-1230 transmission electron microscope (TEM) with acceleration voltage of about 80kV and JEOL-SEM scanning electron microscope (SEM), respectively. X-ray powder diffraction patterns of various solids were determined using a Bruker diffractometer (Bruker D 8 advance target). The patterns were using Cu Kα radiation source with secondly monochromator (λ =1.5405Å) at 40kV and 40mA. The scanning rate was 0.2min−1 for phase identification and line broadening profile analysis, respectively. The crystallite size of the phases present in pure and variously supported solids was determined using the Scherrer equation [38], (1) d = K λ β 1 / 2 cos θ where d is the mean crystalline diameter, λ is the X-ray wavelength, K is the Scherrer constant (0.89), β1/2 is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the main diffraction peaks of the crystalline phase present and θ is the diffraction angle. The wastewater effluents were characterized and analyzed for chemical oxygen demand (COD) according to the procedures described in Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater (APHA, AWWA, 1995) [29]. The photocatalytic reaction was irradiated by UV lamp (λ =254nm). Chemical oxygen demand (COD) was carried out via a Hach-2000 spectrophotometer using a dichromate solution as the oxidant in strong acid media using closed reflux, colorimetric method according to APHA (1995) section 5220-D. The concentration of organic components in the waste water was 200mg/L and COD value was 2042. 2.2.1 Synthesis of DPTS The catalyst [(4-(N,N-dimethylamino)pyridinium-4-toluenesulfonate)] DPTS was prepared by reacting equimolar ratio of complex of 4-(dimethylamino)pyridine and p-toluene sulfonic acid to form the complex according to Moore and Stupp method [39]. The typical procedure is: 7.06g (36.35mmol) of p-toluene sulfonic acid monohydrate, p-TSA, was dissolved in 110mL of benzene and boiled for 3h at 70°C under azeotropic distillation, the water separation was observed. Meanwhile, the solution of 40mL benzene contains 4.4g (35.8mmol) of N,N-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) was heated up to 600°C in 150mL beaker. The hot DMAP was then added drop wise through dropping funnel to the hot p-TSA solution under stirring, the white precipitate of [(4(dimethylamino)pyridinium-4-toluenesulfonate)] (DPTS) began to appear. The reaction was left under stirring for 1h at the same reflux temperature. After cooling, the solution was filtered and carefully washed with benzene then dried under vacuum at 80°C. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 2.2 (CH3, 3H); 3.1 (CH3, 6H); 6.93:6.94 (ArH, 2H, d); 7.07:7.09 (ArH, 2H, d); 8.16:8.17 (NH, 1H). 2.2.2 Synthesis of hyperbranched polyester (HPES-OH) Method of synthesis as was reported [40] and can be described as follows: 3.2g (11.14mmol) of 4,4-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) valeric acid (AB2-monomer) and 0.57g (1.93mmol) DPTS are charged in two necks round bottom flask filled with argon gas. 15mL dry DMF was added via a syringe and the mixture was stirred for 30min. 14.7mmol of coupling reagent [dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC)] was added and stirring at room temperature under argon was continued for 24h. Once the reaction was completed, the urea derivative formed was filtered out and carefully washed with DMF. Then the polymer solution was precipitated in methanol and dried at 50°C under vacuum. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): 9.1T-9.2L (OH), 6.65–7.16m (aromatic H), 2.26T-2.38L (CH2) 1.48T-1.51L (CH3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6): 172.38 (C-1), 155.83 (C-9′L), 155.62 (C-9′T), 148.95 (C-9D), 148.76 (C-9L), 147.25 (C-6D), 145.70 (C-6L), 139.65 (C-6′T), 138.59 (C-6′L), 128.00 (C-7L), 127.90 (C-7D and C-7′T), 121.92 (C-8D), 121.74 (C-8L), 115.42 (C-8′L), 115.26 (C-8′T), 44.95 (C-4D), 44.45 (C-4L), 43.97 (C-4T), 36.17 (C-3), 31.28 (C-2D), 30.41 (C-2T), 27.66 (C-5T), 27.42 (C-5L). FTIRcm−1: υ =3350 (OH), 3060 (CH aromatic), 2970 (CH), 1720 (CO). 2.2.3 Synthesis of the titanate nanowires (TiO2 NWs) The milky suspension formed from mixing 0.2g of TiO2 nanoparticles (P25) in 40mL (10M) NaOH was placed into Teflon lined autoclave. The mixture was then hydrothermally treated at 240°C for 3days. The produced white precipitate (hydrogen titanate nanowire) was separated by filtration, washed and immersed in an aqueous solution of (1.0M) NaCl for 3 days under stirring to get the sodium form Na2Ti n O2n+1 nanowires. The resultant material was washed carefully several times and dried overnight at 80°C. 2.2.4 Synthesis of HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposite (ex situ) Nanocomposites HPES-OH/TiO2NWs (ex situ) was prepared by dissolving 1g of HPES-OH in 22mL of THF (10wt %) then 1.2g of sodium titanate nanowires was added. The mixture was sonicated for 30min and then left under vigorous stirring for 4 days. Finally, the resulted suspension was filtered out and washed by THF then dried under vacuum at 50°C. 2.2.5 Synthesis of HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposite (in situ) Nanocomposites, HPES/TiO2NWs (in situ), were fabricated by performing the polymerization reaction of AB2 monomer in presence of the TiO2 NWs. Accordingly, 2-neck round bottom flask was evacuated and filled with argon then loaded with 1g of sodium titanate nanowires which was dispersed into 20mL dry DMF containing 1g (3.5×10−3 mol) of 4,4-bis(4-hydroxy phenyl) valeric acid. The whole mixture was sonicated for 30min then was left under vigorous stirring for 4 days. 0.17g DTPS was added to the previous mixture and left 30min followed by addition in portions of then 0.9g of 1,3-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC). The whole mixture was left under stirring at room temperature for 24h. The white precipitate, which contains mixture of the urea derivative, DCC-urea, and the nanocomposite was filtered out and carefully washed with hot DMF to get rid of the formed DCC-urea and the excess hyperbranched polymer, followed by 3 times washing with distilled water. Finally, the purified HPES/TiO2-NWs nanocomposite was dried under vacuum overnight at 80°C. 3 Results and discussion Hyperbranched polyester with OH end groups was prepared by solution polymerization of AB2 monomer in presence of catalyst couples DPTS and DCC at room temperature [40]. Unlike the conventional bulk polycondensation method, this procedure yields HBP of high molecular weight with narrow molar mass distribution. This method was successfully used for the synthesis of other dendritic [41] and hyperbranched polyester [42]. Chemical structure of the obtained polymer was confirmed by 1H (Fig. 1 ), 13C NMR and FTIR spectroscopy. The number average molecular weight of the obtained polymer was measured to be Mn=6400g/mol while the degree of polymerization (DP) was found to be 25 as calculated from the relation: (2) DP = Mn − M ( H 2 O ) M ( monomer ) − M ( H 2 O ) 1H and 13C NMR signals were identified and the different subunits (dendritic D, terminal T and linear L) present in the polymer backbone were assigned. The degree of branching (DB) was calculated according to Frechet equation using intensities of C4 in the 13C spectra and found to be 66.5%. The relatively low molar mass and degree of branching could be attributed to low reaction time which was 24h. To get higher molar masses using solution polymerization, it requires more than 40h reaction time but in this case there will be greater opportunity for cyclization reactions which are not favorable in our application. Moreover, surface modification of inorganic nanowires requires both large number of OH end groups and low molecular weight polymers in order to get complete surface coverage of the nanowire. Synthesis of TiO2-NWs was carried out using hydrothermal method in presence of alkaline medium which yields TiO2-NWs in the hydrogen form. Fig. 2a shows SEM image of the formed NWs after washing with NaCl to get the sodium form. It should be noticed that the reaction time and temperature in the autoclave are crucial for both length and diameter of the formed NWs, since higher temperature (up to 240°C) and long reaction time are important factors for crystalline growth with no defects. Fig. 2b reveals the TEM image of TiO2 NWs with average diameter 40nm. Beside, the established nanowires morphology was preserved throughout complete ion exchange of H+ with Na+ during washing with NaCl solution. Synthesis of HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites was carried out using both ex situ and in situ methods in order to study the effect of preparation method on the different properties of the formed nanocomposites. SEM investigations of HPES-OH/TiO2 prepared by ex situ method showed entangled nanowires acquiring a mean length >10μm and 300nm diameter (Fig. 3 ). The synthesis of HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites was also achieved by in situ method through the sonication of the TiO2 (Na+) NWs with solution of the monomer before polymerization as described before. The SEM image of the obtained nanocomposites as depicted in Fig. 4 reveals that the nanowires are separated from each other (unlike in case of ex situ method). Which suggest that the interaction between the polymer and TiO2 NWs is more in the interlayer spaces of the inorganic material than on the outermost surface of the NWs. The X-ray spectra of pure TiO2-NWs and nanocomposites prepared either by in situ or ex situ were determined. Fig. 5 reveals the following. (i) The presence of monoclinic Na2Ti3O7 phase (with crystallite size=79.8nm) (2θ =10.5° (100), 25.7° (110) and 29.7° (103)) [72-0148 JCPDS-ICDD, Copyright 2001] beside the presence of monoclinic H2Ti3O7 phase in TiO2 NWs prepared in situ only [47-0561 JCPDS-ICDD, Copyright 2001]. (ii) Treating TiO2 with polymer ex situ did not change the position of the observed peaks; unlike in case of in situ treatment. (iii) Changes in the crystallite size and degree of crystallinity due to treatment with HPES-OH depend on the method of treatment. The values of crystallite size of pure nanowires, HPES-OH/TiO2 (in situ) and HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites (ex situ) are 79.8nm, 50.7nm and 37nm, respectively. These results showed that modified TiO2 NWs with HPES-OH has reduced crystallite size, which suggest that this treatment could improve the particle morphology and retard the grain growth of TiO2. Moreover, the obtained result confirms the electrostatic interaction between the polar groups in the polymer skeleton (e.g. CO) and TiO2 in the form of coordinate bonds [43]. Chemical structure investigation of the prepared nanocomposites was performed using FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 6 ). The spectrum of HPES-OH shows a strong band at 3340cm−1 which is attributed to phenolic OH groups and a band at 1752cm−1 related to CO of the ester group present in the polymer backbone. By observing the spectra of prepared nanocomposites it can be noticed that the absorption band of CO group was shifted to lower wavenumber and appears as a broad band at 1583cm−1. It was assumed that a Ti-carboxylate was formed which was responsible for the band shift. Ibrahim et al. [44] reported that the coordination between the CO group and the metal can cause a shift in the stretching band up to 200cm−1 which investigated in the prepared nanocomposites. It can be also noticed that the characteristic band of HPES-OH group was intensively shifted toward lower wavenumber indicating the formation of strong interamolecular coordination bonds with the wire surface. Moreover, all the characteristic peaks of HPES-OH were switched to lower wave numbers which emphasis the efficient and strong interaction between TiO2 surface and the polymer chains. The fact that presence of large number of hydroxyl groups on the surface of HPES-OH in turn leads to facilitate the formation of strong bonding with the titanium dioxide nanowires. According to the obtained results it can be claimed that the polymer chains were not only covered the outermost surface of the NWs but also they were strongly incorporated between the nanowires layers to produce 2D network forming belts like morphologies. 3.1 Photocatalytic properties Photocatlytic reactivity of unmodified NWs and surface modified nanowires with HBP, was investigated through addition of different concentrations of the photocatalyst to polluted water and monitoring the efficient removal of COD. As a matter of fact, the amount of catalyst is one of the main parameters for the degradation studies. However, in order to avoid the use of excess catalyst, it was necessary to find out the optimum catalyst loading for efficient removal of COD of the wastewater. Several authors have investigated the reaction rate as a function of catalyst loading in photocatalytic oxidation process [30–32]. The effect of catalyst weight on the percentage removal of COD was investigated from 0.2 to 1.25g/L of the catalyst, in this study a concentration of 0.2g/L was used. Fig. 7 shows the results of photodegradation process, only irradiation with UV without any catalyst and then in presence of pure TiO2 NWs, HPES-OH or HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites prepared using in situ and ex situ techniques. The results reveal that: (i) treatment of wastewater with only UV have no effect. (ii) The maximum percentages of COD removal were 32%, 62.6%, 70% and 69% in case of using HPES-OH only, TiO2-NWs, in situ HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites and ex situ nanocomposites, respectively for 160min reaction time. This might be attributed to smaller crystallite size formed due to modification process. The low COD value obtained on using TiO2-NWs was due to lack of enough OH groups on the NWs surface since they were in the Na-form. It also can be noticed that duration of 60min was sufficient for removal of wastewater using in situ HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites since no further change could be observed by increasing reaction time. COD value of 70% was attained after only 40min reaction time on using HPES-OH/TiO2. Moreover, the degradation rate was fast at the beginning of the photocatalytic process but the removal rate became slower at the end of the reaction which might be due to the formation of intermediate compounds in the wastewater. Hence, the competition between the intermediate compounds and the parent molecules in the photocatalytic degradation process slow down the process rate. It was reported that the photocatalytic efficiency of pollutant degradation was usually decreased due to the mass transfer limitation when some materials without adsorption ability, such as glass and stainless steel are used as supports [45]. In order to enhance the mass transfer, some sorbents as the supporter of photocatalyst have drawn the attention of researchers. These sorbents used often contain silica gel [46], zeolite [47] and activated carbon (AC) [48]. Photocatalytic activity of HPES-OH was found to be 32% which indicates that HPES-OH has limited adsorption ability due to presence of large number of OH terminal groups. However, obtained COD values of HPES/TiO2 confirm that presence of HPES-OH has synergetic effect on the photocataltyic ability of TiO2 NWs, i.e. photocatalytic efficiency of pollutant degradation increased due to enhancement of mass transfer. Moreover, presence of inorganic semiconductor with organic moiety might increase band gab of the semiconductor and hence enhance the photocatalytic activity since it prevents the recombination of the produced photoelctrons and holes due to photocatalytic reaction. The percentage removal of the COD values were slightly higher in case of using HPES-OH/TiO2 in situ (70%) than in case of using NWs modified by ex situ method (69%) which might be smaller crystallite size are obtained on using in situ method than in case of the ex situ technique. Moreover, it was reported [49] that a composite of two inorganic semiconductors enhances photocatalytic activity since such composite reduces the recombination of the photogenerated electrons and holes. The obtained results showed that this finding was true also in case of composites of inorganic semiconductor and a polymer. Durability of the different systems was investigated through using the same materials in a second run and examining their photocatalytic activity with time. Fig. 8 presents the following: (i) generally speaking, in all samples, the photocatalytic activity was reduced in the second run. The decrease was more pronounced in case of using TiO2-NWs (33%) which might be attributed to consumption of the most of surface OH groups in the first run. (ii) The reduction of photocatalytic activity of either HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites in situ or ex situ, was 22% and 25%, respectively. Careful inspection of the figure shows that the decomposition rate at the beginning of the process was much higher in case of using modified NWs, i.e. after 20min the COD value reaches 42% in case of HPES-OH/TiO2 (ex situ). These results confirmed that the nanocomposites possessed good performance after repeated periods in the photocatalytic degradation system. It was of significant importance to examine the TiO2 NWs and nanocomposites prepared either by in situ or ex situ techniques after photocatalytic reaction. The XRD patterns in Fig. 9 reveals the main peaks of HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites (in situ) recovered its position after photocatalytic reaction. Which suggest that the HPES-OH inserted between TiO2 layers and caused main peak shift was liberated. 4 Conclusion Nanocomposites based on hyperbranched polyester with OH end groups and TiO2 NWs in sodium form were prepared by both in situ and ex situ methods. The characterization of prepared nanocomposites revealed that in situ method for preparation yielded well defined TiO2 NWs with homogeneous surface coverage and the morphology was changed to belt form. Electrostatic interaction occurred between OH ends of HPES-OH and TiO2 in the sodium form which lead to smaller crystallite size but maintained its morphology as confirmed by XRD pattern. Photocatalytic activity of the synthesized nanocomposites along with pure TiO2-NWs was examined. The COD analysis confirmed the mineralization of wastewater via photocatalytic degradation using different forms of catalysts. Modified TiO2 showed higher photocatalytic activity than the unmodified ones due to smaller crystallite size. The results suggest that using nanocomposites in wastewater treatment was not only successful but reduces process time to large extent as well. Durability of HPES-OH/TiO2 (in situ and ex situ) was investigated and the results showed that utilization of HPES-OH/TiO2 in the second run was better than TiO2 NWs, i.e. HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites possess good performance after repeat running in photocatalytic degradation system. It should be pointed out that strong adhesion between the polymer and TiO2-NWs was formed through both coordination and hydrogen bondings. coredata.dc:description: TiO2 nanowires (NWs) were prepared by hydrothermal treatment of TiO2 nanoparticles in alkaline medium, while hyperbranched polyester HPES-OH was prepared by polycondensation. Chemical structure of HPES-OH was confirmed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy, FTIR and the molar mass was determined using gel permeation chromatography (GPC). Nanocomposites based on HPES-OH and TiO2 NWs are synthesized either by ex situ method or by in situ technique. Formation of the nanocomposites and investigation of their morphology were done using transmission electron microscope (TEM), scanning electron microscope (SEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). Photocatalytic activity of the synthesized nanocomposites compared to that of pure TiO2-NWs was studied. The chemical oxygen demand (COD) analysis confirmed the mineralization of wastewater via photocatalytic degradation. The results showed that not only photocatalytic activity of nanocomposites was much higher than that of the pure TiO2-NWs, but also the degradation time was reduced to large extent. This result can be attributed to reduction of the crystallite size produced due to the modification reaction. Durability of HPES-OH/TiO2 nanocomposites was investigated and the results confirmed that utilization of the modified TiO2-NWs in the second run was favorable, which suggests that strong adhesion between the NWs and HPES-OH was achieved through the formation of 2D structure.
coredata.dc:title: Photocatalytic activity of hyperbranched polyester/TiO2 nanocomposites
